content:
The longest implication chain I got based on the (.dot) data from Graphiti is 1043 → 434 → 1060 → 109 → 849 → 851 → 1257 → 1256 → 11 → 444 → 850 → 858 → 1064 → 823 → 8 → 3319 → 3253 → 1 but 109 → 849 is not an implication based on the data from Equation Explorer.
(Perhaps the conversion to .dot is wrong, or networkx has a bug, but it'd still be good to know)

These equations are equivalent. The implication 109=>849 is a trivial substitution, the other way is the two theorems starting here:
https://github.com/teorth/equational_theories/blob/main/equational_theories/Generated/VampireProven/Proofs12.lean#L1649

Amir Livne Bar-on schrieb:

These equations are equivalent. The implication 109=>849 is a trivial substitution, the other way is the two theorems starting here:
https://github.com/teorth/equational_theories/blob/main/equational_theories/Generated/VampireProven/Proofs12.lean#L1649

Perfect. Thank you! Then I am assuming that this is the longest implication chain (but the equivalent equations make it a bit messy - we need a means of compressing those structures as well as some sort of entropy measure for this).
Michael Bucko has marked this topic as resolved.

I'm not sure how you calculated this from the graphiti data, as most edges are between vertices in an equivalence class and the graphiti data should be the graph condensation. If you want to include edges within an equivalence class, the longest chain would be much longer (by including equation 2 which should add ~1.5k nodes.)
I used the .dot file from Graphiti and networkx. That's why I was asking. Perhaps the .dot file is not up to date? or perhaps I have a bug? (or networkx has a bug?)
I'm not sure how you could get edges within an equivalence class from the data unless you uncondensed the graph yourself, as graphiti uses the condensed graph representation.

It's from a couple of days ago, I guess. But yeah maybe it's a bug. If you can confirm that the .dot file is up to date / okay, we can close this ticket (if the dot file is right, then I probably have a bug somewhere).
perhaps this is the wrong dot? This file doesn't have 1043 or many of the other equations
You helped me already. I assumed that the "Download DOT" will give me the entire graph, regardless of the URL (incl. the GET vals). If not, then it's my mistake.
Ah yes, the download DOT only gives you the DOT for a specific graph instance
